snippet: The General Assembly is winding down its session after taking up a steady stream of legislation on issues like capital punishment, medical marijuana, the minimum wage and alcohol sales on Sunday.
abstract: Connecticut General Assembly approves Gov Dannel P Malloy's compromise agreement to spend nearly $100 million on improving the state's schools and overhauling the evaluations of teachers; agreement comes near end of legislative session vividly at odds with the prevailing conservative trends in many other states. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD -- In the second hectic and contentious year of Dannel P. Malloy's tenure as governor, Connecticut lawmakers will race the clock on Wednesday to conclude a legislative session characterized by efforts to bridge an unexpected budget deficit, pass Democratic social legislation and address the nation's largest achievement gap between schools in rich and poor neighborhoods. Just as Governor Malloy's first session proved rocky after unions almost scuttled a deal to close one of the nation's worst deficits, this one has proved vexing as well. He pushed for an education package that drew bitter opposition from traditional Democratic allies in teachers' unions because of tough language on tenure and teacher accountability.

headline.main: For Connecticut Governor, A Less-Willing Legislature
